awd_titl_txt: Enhancement of Air Cavities for Ship Drag Reduction
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine vessels are the dominant transportation means in the global trade of goods, as well as a major consumer of fossil fuels. Reducing the hydrodynamic resistance of ships can substantially decrease energy consumption and emissions. A promising technique for drag reduction in water involves air-ventilated cavities formed on the underwater portion of surface ship hulls. These cavities can decrease the hull wetted area and therefore ship drag. However, it is difficult to create and sustain stable large-area air cavities on real ship hulls in broad operational conditions. The proposed research will investigate the application of hydrodynamic actuators for enhancing air-ventilated cavities and maintaining their effectiveness in adverse regimes. Educational activities of this program will result in improving engineering curriculum, developing a new course on drag reduction and flow control, involving undergraduate students in research, and organizing workshops for K-12 summer camps. 

Air-ventilated cavities can be formed by supplying air into water flow around completely or partially immersed solid objects. Characteristics of the flow with air cavities restricted by solid surfaces depend on many factors, including hull geometry, speed, gravity, air supply, and fluid properties. Waves inside the cavities and shedding of air pockets from the cavities add to this complexity. The drag reduction potential of the air cavities is often compromised by non-optimal operating conditions, resulting in short or unstable cavities. The influence of compact actuators on the air-cavity properties and hull resistance will be investigated in a range of important factors. Promising actuator candidates include interceptors, hydrofoils, morphing surfaces, and variable air supply. The investigation will involve experimental studies with model-scale hulls and computational simulations with the state-of-the-art modeling tools. The focus of these efforts will be on understanding and controlling the conditions that produce efficient flow regimes, resulting in formation of stable large-area cavities at small air supply rates. The results will guide the development of practical air-cavity drag reduction systems and will advance knowledge on multi-phase flows and flow control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Reducing water drag of marine vessels can lead to significant decrease of fossil fuel consumption and pollutant emission. A promising technique to reduce water resistance involves air-ventilated cavities formed on underwater surfaces of ship hulls. However, maintaining large-area air cavities at minimal air supply rates in broad operational conditions is challenging. Our primary goal in this project was to investigate effectiveness of compact actuators, variable air injection, and novel hull configurations for enhancing drag-reducing air cavities in water flow. We conducted experiments and numerical modeling with a variety of compact actuators, including hydrofoils, flaps and interceptors, and determined their favorable positions to keep large air cavities under hulls in adverse operational conditions. Time-variable air supply rates was shown to be effective for mitigating degradation of air cavities caused by intensive air shedding in large waves. Compact fences on hydrofoils were found to increase lift and lift-drag ratio of surface-piercing hydrofoils. Important aspects of high-fidelity computational modeling, such as local mesh refinements and use of sharpening factor, were identified through validation studies of air-ventilated water flows in simplified laboratory setups, including high-Reynolds-number regimes. Coupled fluid-structure modeling showed promising configurations of ventilated flexible hydrofoils to achieve desirable hydrodynamic properties in a broad range of conditions. Scaled air-cavity boats were constructed, instrumented, and tested. The obtained test data were used for validation of numerical simulations of realistic hull geometries. Special hull forms that can take advantage of natural air ventilation, as well as morphing and multi-step hull shapes that can extend favorable for air-cavity drag reduction operational range, were computationally explored. Unsteady modeling of air-cavity hulls demonstrated their potential for improving boat seaworthiness in rough seas. A lumped-element model was developed to predict acoustic resonance of air cavities in regular waves. Several novel air-cavity hulls, transformable boat configurations, and underwater actuators are fabricated and tested in water. New technical results obtained in this project can help widen applicability of air-cavity ships, leading to improved sustainability of maritime industry. With support of this grant, several graduate and undergraduate students received training in advanced areas of hydrodynamics and marine systems. Our outreach and educational activities included efforts to attract and retain students in engineering, disseminate research results, and enhance engineering courses with novel topics.
